ai-mn84:1.2_0: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying near Madhurā, in Gunda’s Grove.
ai-mn84:2.2_0: “It seems the ascetic Kaccāna is staying near Madhurā, in Gunda’s Grove.
ai-mn84:2.4_0: ‘He is astute, competent, clever, learned, a brilliant speaker, eloquent, mature, a perfected one.’
ai-mn84:2.5_0: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
ai-mn84:3.1_0: Then King Aṅgīrasa had the finest carriages harnessed. He then mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out in full royal pomp from Madhurā.
ai-mn84:3.2_0: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached Mahākaccāna on foot.
ai-mn84:3.2_1: and after going, he exchanged greetings with him.
ai-mn84:3.2_2: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-mn84:3.2_3: They bowed, sat down to one side, and said to Mahākaccāna:
ai-mn84:4.2_0: ‘Only brahmins are the highest caste; other castes are inferior.
ai-mn84:4.3_0: Only brahmins are the light caste; other castes are dark.
ai-mn84:4.4_0: Only brahmins are purified, not others.
ai-mn84:4.5_0: Only brahmins are Brahmā’s rightful sons, born of his mouth, born of Brahmā, created by Brahmā, heirs of Brahmā.’
ai-mn84:4.6_0: What does you say about this?”

ai-mn84:5.10_0: Suppose an aristocrat prospers in money, grain, silver, or gold. Wouldn’t there be aristocrats, brahmins, merchants, and workers who would get up before him and go to bed after him, and be obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely?”
ai-mn84:5.13_0: and workers get up before him and go to bed after him, and is obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely?”

ai-mn84:5.30_0: And the brahmin Protector would get up before him and go to bed after him, and be obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely?”

ai-mn84:5.44_0: If this is so, are the four castes equal or not?
ai-mn84:5.45_0: Or how do you see this?”
ai-mn84:5.46_0: “Certainly, Master Kaccāna, in this case these four castes are equal.
ai-mn84:5.47_0: I can’t see any difference between them.”

ai-mn84:6.1_0: What do you think, Great King,
ai-mn84:6.2_0: Take an aristocrat who kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct; uses speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; and is covetous, malicious, and has wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, would they be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell, or not?
ai-mn84:6.3_0: Or how do you see this?”
ai-mn84:6.4_0: “Such an aristocrat would be reborn in a bad place.
ai-mn84:6.5_0: That’s what I think, but I’ve also heard it from the perfected ones.”
ai-mn84:6.7_0: It’s good that you think so, and it’s good that you’ve heard it from the perfected ones.

ai-mn84:7.5_0: That’s what I think, but I’ve also heard it from the perfected ones.”

ai-mn84:8.1_0: What do you think, great king?
ai-mn84:8.2_0: Take an aristocrat who breaks into houses, plunders wealth, steals from isolated buildings, commits highway robbery, and commits adultery. Suppose your men arrest him and present him to you, saying:
ai-mn84:8.3_0: ‘Your Majesty, this is a bandit, a criminal.
ai-mn84:8.5_0: What would you do to him?”
ai-mn84:8.6_0: “I would have him executed, fined, or banished, or dealt with as befits the crime.
ai-mn84:8.8_0: Because he’s lost his former status as an aristocrat, and is just reckoned as a bandit.”

ai-mn84:9.1_0: What do you think, great king?
ai-mn84:9.2_0: Take an aristocrat who shaves off their hair and beard, dresses in ocher robes, and goes forth from the lay life to homelessness. They refrain from killing living creatures, stealing, and lying. They abstain from eating at night, eat in one part of the day, and are celibate, ethical, and of good character.
ai-mn84:9.3_0: What would you do to him?”
ai-mn84:9.4_0: “I would bow to them, rise in their presence, or offer them a seat. I’d invite them to accept robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And I’d organize their lawful guarding and protection.
ai-mn84:9.6_0: Because they’ve lost their former status as an aristocrat, and are just their father.
ai-mn84:9.7_0: What do you think, great king?

ai-mn84:10.1_0: When he had spoken, King Avantiputta of Madhurā said to Mahākaccāna,
ai-mn84:10.3_0: Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what had been hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that one with eyes might see what’s there—
ai-mn84:10.3_1: just so has the Dhamma been explained by the dear Kaccāna in many ways.
ai-mn84:10.4_0: I go for refuge to Master Kaccāna, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
ai-mn84:10.5_0: From this day forth, may Master Kaccāna remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ai-mn84:10.6_0: “Great king, don’t go for refuge to me.
ai-mn84:10.7_0: You should go for refuge to that same Blessed One to whom I have gone for refuge.”
ai-mn84:10.8_0: “But where is that Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”
ai-mn84:10.9_0: “Great king, the Buddha has already become fully extinguished.”
ai-mn84:11.1_0: “Master Kaccāna, if I heard that the Buddha was within ten leagues, or twenty, or even up to a hundred leagues away, I’d go a hundred leagues to see him.
ai-mn84:11.2_0: If I heard that the Buddha was within twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, or even up to a hundred leagues away, or even up to a hundred leagues away, we would go a hundred leagues to see him.
ai-mn84:11.3_0: If I heard that the Buddha was within a hundred leagues away, I’d go a hundred leagues to see him.
ai-mn84:11.4_0: But since the Buddha has become fully extinguished, I go for refuge to that fully extinguished Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
ai-mn84:11.5_0: From this day forth, may Master Kaccāna remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ai-mn84:11.6_0: The fourth section on Madhurā is finished.
